content: How can I help you today?
I don’t know if I even want to be here, to be honest. My wife pushed me into this, says it’ll help with everything going on at home, but I just don’t see how talking is going to fix anything.

It sounds like you're feeling uncertain about being here and unsure about how talking could help with what's happening at home. It’s understandable to feel that way, especially if you weren’t the one to make this decision. What’s been going on at home that your wife is concerned about?

My wife and I have been having a hard time dealing with our son’s behavior. He’s been acting out a lot, and nothing we’re doing seems to be helping him. It’s putting so much strain on our marriage, and on top of that, I can’t even focus on work or enjoy anything anymore. It all just feels like too much.

It sounds like there’s a lot weighing on you right now—your son’s behavior, the strain it’s putting on your marriage, and the toll it’s taking on your own well-being. It can be exhausting to feel like no matter what you’re doing, nothing is making a difference. How have you been managing through all of this?
Honestly, I’m not sure I’ve been managing it at all. I end up shutting down most of the time. I feel stuck—like every time I try to do something, it just backfires or makes things worse.

It seems like you're feeling overwhelmed, and it’s been hard to find a way forward that doesn’t leave you feeling stuck or defeated. It must be really tough to keep going when efforts to make things better don’t feel like they're working. What do you think has helped you get through moments like these, even just a little?
I don’t know if anything really has. I just keep going because I have to, but it doesn’t feel like I’m actually making progress or helping anyone.

Continuing on even when it feels like you're not making progress shows a lot of strength—it takes determination to keep moving forward when things feel so heavy. It sounds like you care deeply about your family, even if right now it’s hard to see the impact of your efforts. What would you hope could be different, if things felt more manageable?

I’d just want to see my son happy and doing better. I’d want my wife and I to feel like a team again, instead of like we’re just struggling to get through each day. And I’d want to feel like I can actually enjoy time with my family again, instead of feeling so drained all the time.

Those sound like meaningful and heartfelt hopes—for your son to feel happier and be doing better, to reconnect with your wife as a team, and to enjoy being with your family again without feeling so drained. It’s clear how much you value these things. What do you think might need to happen for you to begin moving toward those changes?

I honestly don’t know. I don’t even know where to start. It feels like there’s just too much going on all at once, and every time I try to figure it out, I end up feeling even more lost. Maybe that’s part of why I’m here, even if I didn’t want to be—it’s hard to see a way forward on my own.

It takes a lot to acknowledge those feelings of being lost and overwhelmed, and even more to realize it might help to have some support. It sounds like you’re open to exploring a way forward, even if it’s not clear yet what that looks like. What would it mean for you to begin to feel like things are moving in the right direction?

It would mean feeling like there’s hope—that we’re actually making progress, even if it’s just small steps. Like my son is starting to improve or that my wife and I are on the same page again. Right now, it feels like everything is standing still or getting worse, so any sign of things getting better would mean a lot.

Hope and progress, even in small steps, sound so important to you right now. You’re looking for something to show that the effort you’re putting in is making a difference—for your son, for your marriage, and for you personally. That’s an important desire to hold onto. What’s one small step you think might bring you closer to feeling that sense of hope or progress?

I honestly don’t know. Maybe just figuring out how to actually help my son—it feels like if we could make some progress with him, it might ease a lot of the tension in everything else. But I don’t even know where to start with that.

Focusing on helping your son sounds like a meaningful place to start, especially if easing some of those challenges might bring relief in other areas too. It’s okay that you don’t have all the answers right now—it’s not easy to know exactly where to begin with something this big. What do you think might help you start exploring ways to support him?

I guess maybe talking to someone who knows more about kids and behavioral challenges could help, but honestly, I’m worried it’ll just feel like another thing that doesn’t work. I’m not sure I trust that it’ll make a difference.

It sounds like the idea of reaching out for help with your son feels like both a possible step forward and a source of hesitation—it’s hard to trust that it’ll lead to the change you’re hoping for, especially after feeling stuck for so long. That doubt is understandable. What would it take for you to feel more confident about giving that kind of step a try?

I guess it’d help if I saw that whoever we talked to really understood what we’re going through and could actually give us something practical to work with. I’d need to feel like it’s worth the effort, especially when it already feels like we’re running on empty most of the time.

Wanting to feel understood and to have practical, meaningful steps to work with makes a lot of sense, especially when things already feel so draining. It’s clear that you want to invest your effort in something that feels worthwhile. If you were to explore this further, what would be the best way to take that step without adding too much to what you're already carrying?
